content: I could see blocks being <50% full but then spiking to 100% when basefee drops below specific round-number thresholds (e.g. 10 gwei) due to the backlog of txs. While this is chaotic from a block usage standpoint, it's much better than a less-tolerant alternative from a UX perspective

author: perama
content:
I think that the oscillator pattern won't play out IRL for the following reason:

If the basefee drops to the "crowded level", the next block will become full. Actors will be able to predict that with a lead time of 14s. 

Similarly, the following block will have the max 1.125x price, predictably. The ability to foresee this will allow some parties to use that to their advantage, which mitigates the effect. 

That mitigation is a dampening process (the downward oscillation amplitude is reduced) because the block will now contain the transactions of these active agents. 

The heuristic I am using is induced behaviour change to some minor percentage of participants. Those who use the forecast to modify their fee stand to gain a lot for little cost, and the system benefits from the dampening effect of their action

author: perama
content: I developed this idea when playing gidget-gadget. At every saw tooth I would think: "I could sneak a transaction in right now because the next block is going to balloon and then be empty, ready for mine to be included at marginally higher fee"

author: perama
content:
Which corresponds to a situation where there are:
- zero happy to pay to play users
- many stingy users all camped at one level
- a minority of slightly less stingy active users who, if they act rationally, will get included and "smooth the sawtooth"

author: barnabemonnot
content:
correct, this is a good reason too. though in my mind the most probable scenario is 1. lots of people join to transact at the same time, their wallets set their max-fees to the same value 2. basefee shoots up until it prices everyone out 3. every time basefee lowers to under that backlog of fixed max-fees users it shoots up again (there are lots of people to include!)

but indeed in that case the "empty block" part of the sawtooth need not be empty if more users join the system, but there could still be this flip flop because of the backlog

author: perama
content:
Interesting. 

That's a good point - if 5000 users all use the same wallet at the same time, their fee prediction is the same. (BFx2)

But what if the wallet added some noise to the prediction?

The level would be less crisp, and less likely to create instability
